lines.text: Well, as much as I hate to leave such distinguished company, I have to be on my way.
lines.character: Jane Mitchell, an alias if Jane Emery

lines.text: Where are we going?
Different directions.
lines.character: Jane Mitchell, an alias if Jane Emery

lines.text: Hey, that crate turned over too easy. Something wrong with that spring balance there.
There can't be anything wrong with it. We figured it out to a T.
Yeah, well you better go on to X, Y, Z.
I take it, you've decided to drive.
lines.character: Jane Mitchell, an alias if Jane Emery

lines.text: Yeah, yeah, I think I will. Riding with women drivers always makes me nervous. You know, I take enough chances everyday.
Listen, let me give you a little advice, will you, please. Lay off dames, they'll ruin your future.
Here you are, lady. I hope its what you want.
Oh, I'm sure it will be Frank. You've never let me down yet.
Thanks Jo. I mean, dog gone it, now that you've been made Office Manager, it seems I should call you Miss Sanderson.
Yes. A lot of things have changed since I became an executive. I wonder if its worthwhile, if any woman should climb too high.
Hello Terry.
Hello Fanny, how you doin'?
Fine. I'm havin' a scrumptious time.
Miss Mitchell, meet Miss Sanderson.
How do you do?
How do you do? I'm so glad to meet you. I read a lot about you in a woman's magazine.
lines.character: Jane Mitchell, an alias if Jane Emery

lines.text: Oh, from stenographer to executive or how a woman made good in big business. There's a sequel to it too.
A sequel?
lines.character: Jane Mitchell, an alias if Jane Emery

lines.text: Yes. It's to be called So What.
What's the idea of making a sap out of yourself?
It's my business.
And mine too. I hate to see a man lose his job over a woman.
Hey, what are you doin' way out here?
Oh, don't be cross loverboy. Its my vacation and I want to be near ya.
Yeah, near me and 14 other mechanics.
Oh, I swear I won't even look at another man.
Your promises are false, woman. So, take your torch some other place.
Oh, loverboy, gadgy-wadgy, please forgive me.
Hey, Shorty, see that dame there? She's got a double-reverse, triple-cross play that make Notre Dame look like a lot of croquet players. Ain't that murder. Big Hoosier.
If Miss Mitchell were a boy who would someday inherit 52% of the company, everyone would applaud her for coming out to learn things from the bottom. Well, a girl can have horse sense too!
Will stop being a sap!
lines.character: Jane Mitchell, an alias if Jane Emery
